markdownRemark.html:
Measuring Causal Effects

  • There are three unknown parameters that can be estimated to help measure causal effects:

    • ATEATEATE: Average treatment effect
    • ATTATTATT: Average treatment effect for the treatment group
    • ATUATUATU: Average treatment effect for the control group
  • The parameter ATEATEATE is dependent on ATTATTATT and ATUATUATU
  • If ATEATEATE is positive and large, then the treatment has a large, positive effect on average (compared to the control group)
  • If ATEATEATE is negative and large, then the treatment has a large, negative effect on average (compared to the control group)
  • If ATEATEATE is small or 000, then the treatment doesn't really have any effect on average (compared to the control group)

Defining Average Treatment Effects

  • The formula for ATEATEATE is defined as the following:
ATE=E[δ]=E[Y1−Y0]\bold{ATE} = E[\delta] = E[Y^{1} - Y^{0}]ATE=E[δ]=E[Y1−Y0] =y01+y11+...+yn1n−y00+y10+...+yn0n= \frac{y_{0}^{1} + y_{1}^{1} + ... + y_{n}^{1}}{n} - \frac{y_{0}^{0} + y_{1}^{0} + ... + y_{n}^{0}}{n}=ny01​+y11​+...+yn1​​−ny00​+y10​+...+yn0​​
  • Here, each yiy_{i}yi​ represents one known observation or one unknown observation (either from the control or treatment group)
  • We can use SDOSDOSDO to estimate the population parameter ATEATEATE

  • And, SDOSDOSDO represents the simple difference in means

    • Again, ATEATEATE is a theoretical, unknown population parameter
    • Whereas, SDOSDOSDO is an actual, known estimator or statistic

  • In practice, SDOSDOSDO is a naive estimation of ATEATEATE

    • There are more sophisticated methods for estimating ATEATEATE
    • Such as, subclassification, matching, etc.

Estimating the Unknown ATEATEATE Parameter

  • The following formula for SDOSDOSDO is defined as the following:
ATE^=SDO=E[Yi1∣ti=1]−E[Yi0∣ti=0]\hat{ATE} = SDO = E[Y_{i}^{1} | t_{i} = 1] - E[Y_{i}^{0} | t_{i} = 0]ATE^=SDO=E[Yi1​∣ti​=1]−E[Yi0​∣ti​=0] =y01+y11+...+yj1+ym1m−y00+y10+...+yk0+yp0p= \frac{y_{0}^{1} + y_{1}^{1} + ... + y_{j}^{1} + y_{m}^{1}}{m} - \frac{y_{0}^{0} + y_{1}^{0} + ... + y_{k}^{0} + y_{p}^{0}}{p}=my01​+y11​+...+yj1​+ym1​​−py00​+y10​+...+yk0​+yp0​​
  • Here, each yjy_{j}yj​ represents a known observation from the treatment group of mmm total observations
  • And, each yky_{k}yk​ represents a known observation from the control group of ppp total observations
  • Notice, the unknown observations are excluded for each yjy_{j}yj​ and yky_{k}yk​
  • So, we are making more assumptions by using this as an estimator

Motivating Existing Biases within SDOSDOSDO

  • Again, the SDOSDOSDO estimator makes a few assumptions about ATEATEATE and includes a few biases as a result

  • Specifically, it includes the following biases:

    • Selection bias
    • Heterogeneous treatment effect bias
  • Mathematically, these biases can be depicted in the formula:
SDO=ATESDO = ATESDO=ATE +E[Y0∣ti=1]−E[Y0∣ti=0]⏟Selection bias+ \underbrace{E[Y^{0} | t_{i} = 1] - E[Y^{0} | t_{i} = 0]}_{\text{Selection bias}}+Selection biasE[Y0∣ti​=1]−E[Y0∣ti​=0]​​ +(1−γ)(ATT−ATU)⏟Heterogeneous bias+ \underbrace{(1-\gamma)(ATT-ATU)}_{\text{Heterogeneous bias}}+Heterogeneous bias(1−γ)(ATT−ATU)​​

  • Here, the above notation represents the following:

    • γ\gammaγ is the number of observations in the treatment goup
    • (1−γ)(1-\gamma)(1−γ) is the number of observations in the control group

Describing the Biases within ATEATEATE

  • Selection bias is the inherent difference between the two groups if both received the treatment
  • The heterogenous treatment effect bias is another form of bias
  • Typically, we'll assume that treatment effects are constant
  • Which, will cause ATU=ATTATU = ATTATU=ATT
  • Thus, it will make SDO=ATE+selection biasSDO = ATE + \text{selection bias}SDO=ATE+selection bias

  • These biases can be mitigated through methods like:

    • Subclassification
    • Matching
    • Etc.

Defining Average Treatment Effects for Treatments

  • The formula for ATTATTATT is defined as the following:

    • Here, mmm is the number of observations in the treatment group
ATT=E[δ∣ti=1]=E[Yi1∣ti=1]−E[Yi0∣ti=1]\bold{ATT} = E[\delta | t_{i} = 1] = E[Y_{i}^{1} | t_{i} = 1] - E[Y_{i}^{0} | t_{i} = 1]ATT=E[δ∣ti​=1]=E[Yi1​∣ti​=1]−E[Yi0​∣ti​=1] ≈δ01+δ11+...+δm1m\approx \frac{\delta_{0}^{1} + \delta_{1}^{1} + ... + \delta_{m}^{1}}{m}≈mδ01​+δ11​+...+δm1​​

Defining Average Treatment Effects for Controls

  • The formula for ATUATUATU is defined as the following:

    • Here, ppp is the number of observations in the control group
ATU=E[δ∣ti=0]=E[Yi1∣ti=0]−E[Yi0∣ti=0]\bold{ATU} = E[\delta | t_{i} = 0] = E[Y_{i}^{1} | t_{i} = 0] - E[Y_{i}^{0} | t_{i} = 0]ATU=E[δ∣ti​=0]=E[Yi1​∣ti​=0]−E[Yi0​∣ti​=0] ≈δ00+δ10+...+δp0p\approx \frac{\delta_{0}^{0} + \delta_{1}^{0} + ... + \delta_{p}^{0}}{p}≈pδ00​+δ10​+...+δp0​​

Verifying the Assumption of Independence

  • To draw conclusions about causality, we must verify there isn't any bias between the control and treatment groups
  • To do this, we must check that the following assumption is satisfied:
E[Y0∣t=0]=E[Y0∣t=1]E[Y^{0} | t=0] = E[Y^{0} | t=1]E[Y0∣t=0]=E[Y0∣t=1]

  • Physical randomization can satisfy this assumption of independence (i.e. independent assignment of observations to groups)

    • Physical randomization refers to assigning an observation to a treatment or control group
    • The assignment is random if the groups are as balanced as if they were assigned by flipping a coin

Describing the Assumption of Independence

  • We can assume SDO=ATESDO = ATESDO=ATE when a treatment ttt is assigned to patients independent of their potential outcomes Y0Y^{0}Y0 or Y1Y^{1}Y1
  • In summary, independence implies that the observations in both the treatment and control groups have the same potential outcome on average in the population

  • Independence can be ensured using the following techniques:

    • Physical randomization
    • Conditional independence

  • In reality, achieving independence is difficult and usually unlikely

    • Hence, we must use additional methods like subclassification, matching, etc.

Enforcing Independence with Physical Randomization

  • In other words, all biases are eliminated by randomly assigning observations to a treatment group and control group

  • So, randomization of the treatment assignment would eliminate both selection bias and heterogeneous treatment effect bias

    • Thus, SDOSDOSDO no longer suffers from selection bias
  • Mathematically, randomization of the treatment assignment ensures:
E[Y0∣t=1]−E[Y0∣t=0]=0E[Y^{0} | t = 1] - E[Y^{0} | t = 0] = 0E[Y0∣t=1]−E[Y0∣t=0]=0
  • Again, randomization of the treatment assignment also eliminates any heterogeneous treatment effect bias
  • Since, randomization of the treatment assignment also ensures:
E[Y1∣t=1]−E[Y1∣t=0]=0E[Y^{1} | t = 1] - E[Y^{1} | t = 0] = 0E[Y1∣t=1]−E[Y1∣t=0]=0

More Details about Association and Causation

  • Association refers to a statistical relationship between two variables
  • Causation refers to determing that an exposure of one variable produces an effect on a different variable
  • Association becomes causation if a variable YYY in the treatment group doesn't behave any differently in the control group
  • So, association becomes causation when the following is true:
E[Y0∣T=0]=E[Y0∣T=1]E[Y_{0} | T=0] = E[Y_{0} | T=1]E[Y0​∣T=0]=E[Y0​∣T=1]
  • Here, YtY_{t}Yt​ refers to a variable being measured within the study
  • And, TTT refers to a binary variable representing whether the observation received treatment or not
